channel.title: Grammar Girl Quick and Dirty Tips for Better Writing
channel.itunes:subtitle: Quick and Dirty Tips for Better Writing
channel.itunes:author: QuickAndDirtyTips.com
channel.itunes:summary: Grammar Girl provides short, friendly tips to improve your writing. Whether English is your first language or your second language, these grammar, punctuation, style, and business tips will make you a better and more successful writer. Grammar Girl is a Quick and Dirty Tips podcast. To download podcast episodes not shown here, visit QuickandDirtyTips.com
channel.description: You'll get fun and friendly doses of writing advice in three short chunks: a Quick and Dirty Tip, a meaty middle, and a final tidbit. Grammar Girl covers everything from punctuation and grammar to style and voice. QuickandDirtyTips.com

item.title: 449 GG Double Possessives
item.itunes:subtitle: An easy trick to remember the difference between transitive and intransitive verbs and a discussion of why a sentence such as "He's a friend of Fred's" is so tricky.
item.itunes:summary:
Follow along on the website:
Transitive Versus Intransitive Verbs http://j.mp/1AUkNaZ
Double Possessives http://j.mp/1x8OVy2
Try my iOS game, Grammar Pop http://j.mp/1H5YiSj

item.title: 448 GG How Our Brains Process Hyperbole
item.itunes:subtitle: Champ or Chomp at the Bit. Hyperbole. Adulting.
item.itunes:summary:
Follow along on the website:
Champ Versus Chomp http://j.mp/1Cp9TsZ
Hyperbole http://j.mp/1HkXt6c
Adulting http://j.mp/1sNOALZ

item.title: 447 GG Weird Ideas About Paragraph Length
item.itunes:subtitle: Why some disease names are capitalized, why it's OK to vary your paragraph length, and tidbits about Johannes Gutenberg

item.title: 446 GG Why Don't People Say "Thou" Anymore
item.itunes:subtitle: Xmas Versus Christmas. Why Don't People Say Thou Anymore? Kitty-Corner Versus Catty-Corner

What Does "Xmas" Really Mean? http://bit.ly/1xkSUsL

item.itunes:subtitle: Is "boughten" a word? Did Valley Girls invent "like"? Is German Chocolate Cake from Germany?

item.title: 443 GG Done Versus Finished
item.itunes:subtitle: Done Versus Finished, Types of Nouns, and Why Grimm's Fairy Tales Should Make You Think of Linguistics
item.itunes:summary:
Done Versus Finished (Follow along at the website: http://bit.ly/1uNZgyH) Types of Nouns (http://bit.ly/1vwzG3c) Why Grimm's Fairy Tales Should Make You Think of Linguistics (http://bit.ly/1yzfHOs)
Try my iOS game, Grammar Pop: http://bit.ly/14eeMDb

item.title: 442 GG Make Me a Sandwich
item.itunes:subtitle: Based on Versus Based off. Make Me a Sandwich: A Joke About Verbs. How to Pronounce Zero
item.itunes:summary: Based on Versus Based off. Make Me a Sandwich: A Joke About Verbs. How to Pronounce Zero

item.title: 441 GG Mic or Mike? Simple or Simplistic? Uppercase and Lowercase
item.itunes:subtitle: Mic or Mike? Simple or Simplistic? Uppercase and Lowercase
item.itunes:summary: Mic or Mike? Simple or Simplistic? Uppercase and Lowercase. Visit the website: http://bit.ly/1qEiW2m

item.title: 440 GG How to Plan a Novel
item.itunes:subtitle: For NaNoWriMo: How to format a character's thoughts, how to plan a novel, and the surprising newness of the novel format
item.itunes:summary: For NaNoWriMo: How to format a character's thoughts, how to plan a novel, and the surprising newness of the novel format. Visit the website: http://bit.ly/13DNlJ8

item.title: 439 GG Texting, Coffins, and Death
item.itunes:subtitle: Texting, Coffins, and Death
item.itunes:summary: Today, with Halloween in mind, I have a Quick and Dirty tip about the difference between a casket and a coffin; and an excerpt from David Crystal’s new book, Words in Time and Place, that goes through the many words we have for death and dying. Finally, I saw something shocking in a formal document a few weeks ago, so I have a tidbit about text messaging and language. Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1sXJDC5

item.title: 438 GG Why Do People Say Punctuation Out Loud?
item.itunes:subtitle: Why people say things such as "We never leave any soldier behind. Period."
item.itunes:summary: "Vaccine" Versus "Vaccination." Syelle Graves explains why people say things such as "We never leave any soldier behind. Period," and more generally, the relationship between speech and writing. A doozy of an eighteenth-century grammar rule: Don't use "who" to refer to children. Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1Fc7Lrk

item.title: 437 GG What’s the difference between England, Great Britain, and the UK?
item.itunes:subtitle: What’s the difference between England, Great Britain, and the UK?
item.itunes:summary: I know all you European listeners think it’s ridiculous that Americans don’t know the difference between England and Britain, but a British friend told me that many of you don’t know the difference between Britain and the United Kingdom, and that this would be a good topic for a podcast even though people should already know. Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1D7rupV

item.title: 436 GG Why People Have Always Been Confused About Apostrophes
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Ammon Shea about the confusing history of apostrophes. Hanged Versus Hung. The story of the Victorian Great Exhibition, where Adolphe Sax displayed his invention: the saxophone
item.itunes:summary: An interview with Ammon Shea about the confusing history of apostrophes. Hanged Versus Hung. The story of the Victorian Great Exhibition, where Adolphe Sax displayed his invention: the saxophone. Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/Zsa0po

item.title: 435 GG We Might Could Harvest the Corn
item.itunes:subtitle: Starting a Sentence with "Because," Helping Verbs and Double Modals, and Fascinating Facts About the Dot over the Letter I
item.itunes:summary: Yes, you can start a sentence with "because." Here's how to do it. What are helping verbs (also called auxiliary verbs), and why do people in some regions say things such as "might could" and "might should"? English writers didn't always use a dot over the letter "i." We'll talk about when and why they started. Visit the website: http://bit.ly/1phbhWH

item.title: 434 GG Ya Shank: The Made-Up Swear Words of 'The Maze Runner'
item.itunes:subtitle: Insults, swear words, and world-building for young adults: In an interview with James Dashner, I got the inside scoop on the language of 'The Maze Runner.'
item.itunes:summary: Insults, swear words, and world-building for young adults: In an interview with James Dashner, I got the inside scoop on the language of "The Maze Runner." Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1poctaV

item.title: 433 GG Why People Mix Up the Pronouns "Me" and "I"
item.itunes:subtitle: I can tell you which pronouns to use, but it takes a linguist to explain WHY people get confused. Here, Gretchen McCulloch reveals the fascinating reason that people struggle with sentences such as "Billy and me went to the store. "
item.itunes:summary: I can tell you which pronouns to use, but it takes a linguist to explain WHY people get confused. Here, Gretchen McCulloch reveals the fascinating reason that people struggle with sentences such as "Billy and me went to the store." Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1vrTG2g

item.title: 432 GG When to Use a Comma Before 'Because'
item.itunes:subtitle: A tip about when you need a comma before the word "because," an interview with Peter Sokolowski from Merriam-Webster about the philosophies behind dictionary definitions, and a tidbit the phrase éminence grise.
item.itunes:summary: A tip about when you need a comma before the word "because," an interview with Peter Sokolowski from Merriam-Webster about the philosophies behind dictionary definitions, and a tidbit the phrase éminence grise. Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1yxWmkA

item.title: 431 GG Words That Aren't Words
item.itunes:subtitle: An excerpt from Ammon Shea's book "Bad English"
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, you get a Quick and Dirty Tip about where to put periods and commas relative to quotation marks, an excerpt from Ammon Shea's book "Bad English," and a tidbit about a 1921 poem called "Alphabet of Errors." Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1v0iNsF

item.title: 430 GG The Plural of Money. This Is Your Brain on Writing. Egregious
item.itunes:subtitle: 430 GG The Plural of Money. This Is Your Brain on Writing. Egregious
item.itunes:summary: In this week's podcast, Grammar Girl discusses the plural of money, how to use "egregious," and talks with Ellen Hendriksen from The Savvy Psychologist podcast about the findings from an experiment done by German researchers in Germany who studied people’s brains while they were actively writing. Read the transcript: http://bit.ly/1AUhYp5

item.title: 429 GG How to Use the Conjunction “Nor”
item.itunes:subtitle: 429 GG How to Use the Conjunction “Nor”
item.itunes:summary: How do you use the conjunction "nor" and why is it so special it deserves a podcast of its own? Neil Whitman explains. Visit the website to read the full transcript: http://bit.ly/1oOCyOR

item.title: 428 GG Crash Blossoms
item.itunes:subtitle: Why the Associated Press accidentally made people think another Malaysian airplane had crashed, and what it tells us about language.
item.itunes:summary: Why the Associated Press accidentally made people think another Malaysian airplane had crashed, and what it tells us about language. Visit the website to read the full transcript: http://bit.ly/1rs4BXJ

item.title: 427 GG 7 French Food-Related Words That Became English
item.itunes:subtitle: When the Normans took over England in 1066, they brought their food and their language.
item.itunes:summary: When the Normans took over England in 1066, they brought their food and their language. We talk about seven interesting French words that made it into English, and guest Clever Cookstr shares some of her favorite related recipes. Read the full transcript: http://bit.ly/1octDLT

item.title: 426 GG A Language Lover's Trip to England
item.itunes:subtitle: What you see when you visit England with an eye on the history of English.
item.itunes:summary: During a short but delightful trip to England, I saw the Rosetta Stone, the White Tower at the Tower of London, ancient alphabet tiles and wax seals, a stained glass window honoring William Caxton, and many more wonders. Hear about them all. Read the transcript on the website: http://bit.ly/1o02vuz

item.title: 425 GG Why Weird Al's Word Crimes Video Made Me Want to Quit
item.itunes:subtitle: Why Weird Al's Word Crimes Video Made Me Want to Quit
item.itunes:summary: Why Weird Al's Word Crimes Video Made Me Want to Quit. Visit the website to watch the video and comment: http://bit.ly/1qArtIJ

item.title: 424GG There's Something Weird About "For," "Yet," and "So"
item.itunes:subtitle: FANBOYS are a myth and there's something weird about "for," "yet," and "so."
item.itunes:summary: FANBOYS are a myth and there's something weird about "for," "yet," and "so."

item.title: 423 GG Is the Semicolon in TL;DR Ironic?
item.itunes:subtitle: "TL;DR" means "too long; didn't read," but the semicolon is usually associated with long or complex sentences. What is it doing in this abbreviation?
item.itunes:summary: "TL;DR" means "too long; didn't read," but the semicolon is usually associated with long or complex sentences. What is it doing in this abbreviation? Note: This piece originally appeared as a Grammar Girl blog post January 22, 2014 and was rereleased as an audio podcast on July 3, 2014. Visit the website to read the full transcript and leave a comment: http://bit.ly/1g1PtiA

item.title: 422GG Manipulating Words to Make Things Funny
item.itunes:subtitle: Scopal Ambiguity
item.itunes:summary: Why sentences like this are funny: A woman gives birth in the UK every 48 seconds. She must be exhausted.

item.title: 421GG Part II: Why Do People Say 'A-Whole-Nother'?
item.itunes:subtitle: Learn why 'a-whole-nother' is a lot like 'an apron'
item.itunes:summary: Why do people say "a-whole-nother"?It's the same reason we say "an apron" instead if "a napron."

item.title: 420GG Why 'A-Whole-Nother' Isn’t Like 'Ala-Frickin’-Bama' and 'Hizzouse'
item.itunes:subtitle: While researching why people say 'a-whole-nother,' Syelle Graves discovered that even knowing what to call the phrase gets complicated (and interesting).
item.itunes:summary: While researching why people say "a-whole-nother," Syelle Graves discovered that even knowing what to call the phrase gets complicated (and interesting).

item.title: 419GG Using Stick Figures to Understand First, Second, and Third Person
item.itunes:subtitle: 419GG Using Stick Figures to Understand First, Second, and Third Person
item.itunes:summary: Using Stick Figures to Understand First, Second, and Third Person

item.title: 418GG Starting a Sentence with a Conjunction: Right or Wrong?
item.itunes:subtitle: Many people have been taught that it's wrong to start a sentence with a conjunction, but nearly all major style guides say doing so is fine. Neal Whitman investigates why there seems to be such a difference between what teachers say and what style guides
item.itunes:summary: Many people have been taught that it's wrong to start a sentence with a conjunction, but nearly all major style guides say doing so is fine. Neal Whitman investigates why there seems to be such a difference between what teachers say and what style guides say.

item.title: 417GG An Unparalleled Letdown
item.itunes:subtitle: The authors of "The Blue Book of Grammar and Punctuation" help us understand parallel structure
item.itunes:summary: The authors of "The Blue Book of Grammar and Punctuation" help us understand parallel structure.

item.title: 416GG How to Kick Your Annoying Preposition Habit
item.itunes:subtitle: How to Kick Your Annoying Preposition Habit
item.itunes:summary: How to Kick Your Annoying Preposition Habit

item.title: 415GG Commas Are Like People on the Subway
item.itunes:subtitle: Oxford, Appositive, Nonrestrictive
item.itunes:summary: Commas are like people on the subway: You think you know them, but they're awfully complex. This week, we'll dig deeper and get to know some of their jobs: separating items in a series (the Oxford comma), delineating appositives, and surrounding nonrestrictive phrases.

item.title: 414GG Luisa Zissman's Missing Apostrophe
item.itunes:subtitle: Does Bakers Toolkit Need an Apostrophe
item.itunes:summary: Sometimes companies leave apostrophes out of their names when it seems as if the name would need an apostrophe. Why do they do it, and is it wrong?

item.title: 413GG Words Invented by Shakespeare
item.itunes:subtitle: In honor of Shakespeare's 450th birthday, we'll look at Shakespeare's words, phrases, insults, and false friends. I bet you don't know them all.
item.itunes:summary: In honor of Shakespeare's 450th birthday, we'll look at Shakespeare's words, phrases, insults, and false friends. I bet you don't know them all.

item.title: 412GG Can I Help Who's Next?
item.itunes:subtitle: Why do people say such things?
item.itunes:summary: Neal Whitman addresses some annoying phrases you hear in stores and restaurants, such as "Can I help who's next?" and "Did you want cream in your coffee?" Find out why people say such things.

item.title: 411GG Addictive Versus Addicting
item.itunes:subtitle: Addictive Versus Addicting
item.itunes:summary: Addictive Versus Addicting

item.title: 410GG Just Because
item.itunes:subtitle: Just because you’re correct doesn’t mean you’re not annoying.
item.itunes:summary: It's tricky to pick apart the grammar of a sentence such as "Just because you’re correct doesn’t mean you’re not annoying." Guest writer Neal Whitman explains why such sentences work and what they really mean.

item.title: 409GG More Than Versus Over
item.itunes:subtitle: A big change at the AP Stylebook
item.itunes:summary: Editors from the Associated Press just announced that the AP Stylebook is changing its stance on using "over" to mean "more than." Plenty of people are shocked. Find out why they shouldn't be.

item.title: 408GG Why We Don't End Sentences With "You're"
item.itunes:subtitle: Some words have strong forms, weak forms, and even weaker forms.
item.itunes:summary: Some words have strong forms, weak forms, and even weaker forms.

item.title: 407GG Why Canadians Don't Really Say "Aboot"
item.itunes:subtitle: Why Canadians don't say "aboot" and why most Americans think they do.
item.itunes:summary: Gretchen McCulloch from the All Things Linguistic explains why Canadians don't say "aboot" and why most Americans think they do.

item.title: 406GG Begging the Question
item.itunes:subtitle: Language is changing but that doesn't mean you have to go with the flow.
item.itunes:summary: Language is changing but that doesn't mean you have to go with the flow.

item.title: 405GG Is Cash Money a Regional Expression?
item.itunes:subtitle: Is Cash Money a Regional Expression?
item.itunes:summary: Is Cash Money a Regional Expression?

item.title: 404GG Why "Substitute" Is Weird
item.itunes:subtitle: Why it’s hard to talk about substituting one thing for another without confusing people.
item.itunes:summary:
Why it’s hard to talk about substituting one thing for another without confusing people.
Guest Writer: Neal Whitman Sponsor: AudiblePodcast.com/GG

item.title: 403GG Preventative and Orientate
item.itunes:subtitle: The shorter word is usually the better choice, but don't get carried away and start thinking that choosing the shorter word is a hard-and-fast rule.
item.itunes:summary:
Today, we’re going to talk about two cases in which English has two words that mean the same thing and whether one choice is better than the other. Preventative and preventive, and orient and orientate.
Sponsor: Grammar Girl’s Peeve Wars. Visits FundAnything.com/peevewars to learn more.

item.title: 402GG Little Bunny Foo Foo
item.itunes:subtitle: The Hoax Behind Little Bunny Foo Foo
item.itunes:summary: The Hoax Behind Little Bunny Foo Foo

item.title: 401GG How Clipping Creates New Words
item.itunes:subtitle: Great tales of English word evolution: From pantaloons to pants, caravan to van, and much more.
item.itunes:summary:
Great tales of English word evolution: From pantaloons to pants, caravan to van, and much more.
Guest Writer: Bonnie Trenga
Sponsor: http://FundAnything.com/peevewars

item.title: 400GG How Reading Tickles Your Neurons
item.itunes:subtitle: Studies show that reading fiction actually changes your neurons. It's amazing.
item.itunes:summary:
When you read about a character, in some ways your brain acts as though it thinks you ARE the character. It's amazing. Grammar Girl and the Savvy Psychologist explain how.
Subscribe to the Savvy Psychologist's show at iTunes. Get the card game Peeve Wars at http://FundAnything.com/peevewars

item.title: 399GG Your Brain on Fiction
item.itunes:subtitle: How Literature Changes Your Brain for the Better
item.itunes:summary: How Literature Changes Your Brain for the Better. If you liked this podcast, check out our new show, The Savvy Psychologist.

item.title: 071 Units Of Measure
item.itunes:subtitle: Feet, Ft., Lb., Degrees, and Percents
item.itunes:summary: Units Of Measure: Feet, Ft., Lb., Degrees, and Percents

item.title: 398GG Why Some Band Names Take "The" and Some Don't
item.itunes:subtitle: Why can we say "the Jefferson Airplane" but not "the Led Zeppelin"?
item.itunes:summary: Why can we say "the Jefferson Airplane" but not "the Led Zeppelin"?

item.title: 397GG Secrets of Bestselling Novels
item.itunes:subtitle: A new study uncovered things that successful novels have in common.
item.itunes:summary: A new study uncovered things that successful novels have in common.

item.title: 396 GG Tenterhooks or Tenderhooks?
item.itunes:subtitle: What could this week’s topic be?
item.itunes:summary: What could this week’s topic be?

item.title: 192 Do I Hate Your Singing or You Singing?
item.itunes:subtitle: Do I Hate Your Singing or You Singing?
item.itunes:summary: Do I Hate Your Singing or You Singing?

item.title: 395 GG How to Use Quotation Marks
item.itunes:subtitle: How to mix quotation marks with other punctuation.
item.itunes:summary: How to mix quotation marks with other punctuation.

item.title: 394GG Hashtag Rap
item.itunes:subtitle: Did Kanye West Coin the Term "Hashtag Rap"?
item.itunes:summary: Did Kanye West Coin the Term "Hashtag Rap"?

item.title: 393 GG Nonsense Syllables
item.itunes:subtitle: Why we sing "fa la la" instead of "fra spla spla"
item.itunes:summary: Why we sing "fra la la" instead of "fa spla spla"

item.title: 392 GG Orangehead
item.itunes:subtitle: Why do we call people redheads instead of orangeheads?
item.itunes:summary:
Why do we call people redheads instead of orangeheads? Guest writer Gretchen McCulloch has the amazing answer.
Grammar Pop Winterfest is a new wintery edition of the original Grammar Pop iOS game. It has new winter art and all new sentences, and it's on sale for only 99 cents until December 15. Get it today!

item.title: GG251 What Is a Gerund?
item.itunes:subtitle: What Is a Gerund?
item.itunes:summary: What Is a Gerund?

item.title: 391 GG Scrabble Words
item.itunes:subtitle: A fun romp through some quirky words you may see when you're playing Scrabble.
item.itunes:summary:
A fun romp through some quirky words you may see when you're playing Scrabble.
Remember to check out my new game, Grammar Pop, for your iPhone or iPad.

item.title: 390GG Passive Voice
item.itunes:subtitle: Avoid one of the biggest passive voice mistakes!
item.itunes:summary: Avoid one of the biggest passive voice mistakes!

item.title: 389 GG English Plurals: Wugs and Blicks
item.itunes:subtitle: Your subconscious controls how you speak.
item.itunes:summary:
Your subconscious controls how you speak. We show why you already know how to make imaginary words such as "wugs" and "blicks" plural.
Try the new iPad and iPhone grammar game, Grammar Pop. It's in the App Store.

item.title: 094 Irregardless Versus Regardless
item.itunes:subtitle: Why Is "Irregardless" in the Dictionary?
item.itunes:summary:
"Irregardless" is in most dictionaries. Does that make it a work you can or should use?
Grammar Pop is now available for the iPhone. Look for it in the App Store today!
